reviewText: The War of the Worlds t.v. series came at an interesting time in television history.  In 1988, more and more shows were being directly released in syndication, effectively side-stepping the big networks (and thus big network costs).  I've read that some people saw this on Saturday afternoons, but my Fox affiliate carried it on Friday nights (the well-known graveyard for good sci-fi).As a huge fan of the original 1953 film, I was delighted that the series paid tribute by incorporating footage of that film into its opening credits, as well as a recurring role for that film's female lead, Ann Robinson as Sylvia Van Buren.  The last primetime alien invasion series had been the late, lamented "V."  And War of the Worlds owes as much to that series as to its source film and novel.It's universally acknowledged that the first season was far superior to the second, which changed the format and killed off 2 of its stars in its first episode.  But the first year was pretty solid, detailing the government-sanctioned battle against alien invaders by a small group of people.  Jared Martin as Harrison and Richard Chaves as Ironhorse were standout performers.  True, the syndicated format allowed for some occasionally over-the-top effects (similar to Freddy's Nightmares, also syndicated at the same time; and prefigured the X-Files more graphic scares five years later), which I recall being a turn-off to some fans of the original film.  But War of the Worlds was an action-packed sci-fi series, and one that deserves another look.
summary: Underrated sci-fi series resurrected on DVD!

reviewText: The first season of this show had a good story and plot; however, the acting was horrendous. So much so that I would have given 0 stars for this show had that been an option. Anyone who believes that the first season outplayed the second must not care about quality acting. The second season is watchable whereas, I have to say, the first is almost unwatchable. I would say that the second season is more worth having on DVD than the first, without question. Indeed, the inclusion of Adrian Paul was a big help to the show as I think many will agree. I actually hope they release season 2 on DVD. My advice, just pretend the first season never existed.

reviewText: I remember fondly watching War of the World.  I was very excited in the 80's as a young teen when the show was announced - even going so far as to buy the novelization of the pilot.I probably should have left it there.  Although I'm a fan of chintzy sci-fi (Doctor Who forever!) this show is somewhat of a let-down.The pilot episode is interesting, and fairly suspenseful, but it ultimately let down by very VERY wooden acting from the entire cast.  No one is entirely believable.The effects tend to be gory, but not bloody, which is a shame because this show could have been made much MUCH darker by including either more or less effects-wise.The aliens have found a way to "inhabit" human bodies.  This is apparently LITERAL, with the physical alien INSIDE the host.  Problem is, the few times we see an alien "bust out", there is no blood, no gore, just a rubber hand sticking out of a rubber torso.  Not even the slightest gunge spews from the body.The problem this leads to is, again, believability.  I'm no great fan of bloody gore, but it seems like if something is IN my body and then coming back OUT, I should expel SOME type of "fluid". :)The cheesy effects, bad acting, and often implausible storylines do much to detract from a show I loved in my youth.  I still have a place for it, and it will still get watched.  But if you remember this show "fondly" you might want to give buying it a second (or third) thought.A+ for the fans.  D- for everyone else.

reviewText: At least in its first season, this was one of the most intelligent sci-fi series to come along, with good character development and compelling storylines.  This series first played on Saturday afternoons in NYC, and I used to make a point of not missing it (this was the ancient days before VCR's became household items).  I have never forgotten the episode where one of the heroes lost his beloved, and never knew what happened...excellently done.Of course, since it succeeded, the suits had to change the plotline in the second season, to make it more "relevant to the 18-49 demographic"; it was soon cancelled.
summary: Another series butchered by network suits.

reviewText: Living in the wasteland of South Jersey Cablevision, the Sci-Fi Channel was like manna from God when we finally recieved it in 1995. My television was locked on channel 62 through the reruns of Time Tunnel, Tales From the Darkside, Monsters, The Incredible Hulk, Planet of the Apes, Kolchak...even the toons in the morning like Gigantor and Bionic Six and schlock like Sightings. Saturday nights used to have a back to back run of Alien Nation and War of the Worlds. I remember watching WOTW during it's original run, and noticed some of the edits Sci-Fi made to the show, removing the more over the top gore. Few years ago, I scored a set of dubs from the original run from a Boston TV station, complete with vintage commercials (Dukakis '88, anyone? How about some cookies with smiley faces?) and a promo reel. When I found out that Paramount had released the first season on DVD, I bit. I should've spit.WOTW takes place several decades after the Gene Barry film. We learn that the Martians...err, Mortaxans, didn't really die at the picture's conclusion. Rather, they were hibernating. Instead of say, burning them or sending them back in to space, the government scooped all these sleeping aliens up and put them in drums and left them laying around such places as military depots. Well, along come some terrorists who accidentally revive a gang of these critters. Aliens somehow figure out they can "possess" human bodies and set about waking their buddies up, looking for their spaceships, and causing general mischief. Only within human bodies or weird rubber suits with gas masks can irradiated aliens survive. Now waitaminnit, didn't those germs just summon the sandman, not kill them? Leaps of logic abound.Another weird things is that, well, everyone has amnesia in regards to the film. So, large parts of the world are destroyed and everybody forgets about it because the aliens frightened them? Ohhhkay. The government, which at first doesn't believe the aliens are back, assembles "The Blackwood Project", namely Harrison Blackwood, the adopted son of Dr. Forrester; a biologist named Suzanne McCullough; computer expert Norton Drake; and an uptight army colonel named Paul Ironhorse (Richard Chaves of Predator fame) to combat the buggers. Uh, these aliens nearly destroyed the planet and you throw just four people at them? Overseeing the project is General Wilson (John Vernon of Animal House).The series is pretty silly, owing the inferior scripts after the first few episodes to a writer's guild strike. As a previous reviewer noted, the show was filmed in Ontario, which they pass off as just about anywhere in America possible. One episode that purportedly takes place in Philadelphia contains only a shot up Broad Street towards City Hall. The rest is most certainly NOT the City of Brotherly Love. The aliens make all sorts of odd weapons and inventions out of household appliances, and there's plentiful helpings of dark humor and gore, which is the show's appeal to me. Heck, you might even find yourself rooting for the aliens to win!No, the acting isn't believable. Neither is the science behind the "cell phase matching" by which Mortaxans appropriate human bodies. Premises like the aliens sticking together in threes break down in actual execution. Despite the odds, WOTW captured enough of an audience to be renewed for another season. Paramount foolishly decided to completely rework the series. The Mortaxans and Ironhorse were killed off, and the setting changed to a post-apocalyptic environment. Ratings tanked. The final episodes didn't even run in many markets.Paramount rushed this to tie in with the DVD of Tom Cruise's movie. No question about it. The devoted fans (yes, Virginia, they exist) weren't factored into the equation. The six discs are packaged in three slim plastic cases with the most minimal of artwork. The are NO supplemental materials. Come the hell on, Paramount! Couldn't find the twenty minute promo reel with the SFX guys at work? I'll send it to you, email me. No commentary tracks? How hard to find are the actors or Greg Strangis or the script writers? Jared Martin was actually teaching poor children how to make films in Philadelphia just a few years ago. They didn't even add the commercials or the advance ads for the next episode.Even worse, the prints looks only slightly better than my second generation copies. Seriously, this may be the worst transfer I've ever seen from a major studio. That emcompasses a lot of bad prints, folks. The shot of the alien hand descending over the Earth after the titles has been inexplicably removed. Top to bottom, the entire package bears the stink of a quick cash-in, marketed to unfortunate souls who had never heard of the show but liked the Tom Cruise remake. WOTW wasn't wonderful, but guess what? Even cinematic excrement like Gigli and Glitter received better treatment. Utterly deplorable. See how many used copies are for sale? That's usually a giant "beware" sign as far as projects as obscure as this go. Will Friday the 13th, produced by the same folks as WOTW, suffer the same fate? Time will tell...

reviewText: This was one of the most creative attempts for a SciFi series. The show ran two seasons, though I hated the second season. Mainly because they killed off my two favorite characters (Col. Ironhorse and Norton). In this show a truly integrated group, a white male, a woman, a Native American and a black paraplegic defended the planet from a hostile alien invasion. The series followed the concept that the 1953 Classic 'War of the Worlds' happened (and even incorporated the Orson Wells 1938 broadcast into the show). One of the best parts of this show was bringing Ann Robinson into plot to reprise the role she played in the 1953 classic. For fans of the original War of the Worlds I do recommend this.
summary: A Continuation of the SciFi Classic
Title: N/A

reviewText: Television series designed as a sequel to George Pal's 1953 film of the same name. Builds onto the premise of aliens invading Earth in the 1950's.In the 1953 movie, hundreds of alien spaceships landed around the globe to begin the destruction of mankind. Nothing, including nuclear weapons, could stop the invading spaceships. Entire cities were routed and demolished, global communications disrupted leaving continents cut off from the rest of the world, and presumingly many millions were killed or injured. In the end, mankind was saved only when Earth's common bacteria killed the alien invaders.This television series takes up at that point with a premise that the aliens were not really dead, but only in a state of deep hibernation. Years later (modern times), terrorists, raiding a government storage facility, damage containers of radioactive liquids, killing the bacteria infecting the alien bodies stored nearby, allowing the aliens to come out of hibernation.A college professor,  Dr. Harrison Blackwood, recognizes the danger and rushes to warn others. And this is where the first inconsistency in the television series appears. Nobody, other than Blackwood, seems aware of the 1950's invasion, a threat of another invasion, or even the possibility aliens exist. Instead of an immediate massive government and military response (which one would certainly expect if the human race had been nearly destroyed by aliens just a few decades earlier - the core theme of the series), Blackwood is met with doubts, suspicion, and even questions about his sanity. This blatant inconsistency repeats itself over and over throughout the first season.Regardless, by the end of the first episode, Blackwood is able to convince a few and the military assembles a team of four to fight the new alien invasion - a team of four is unbelievable considering all mankind was not able to stop the first invasion. The team is headed by Harrison Blackwood, a self-styled thinker who absurdly uses a music tuning fork to help him concentrate (actor reminds me of the cheesy singer Tom Jones). He is joined by microbiologist Suzanne McCullough (obviously intended to be the show's babe, without the real qualifications for that), programmer Norton Drake (writers apparently did not know enough about computers to make his role realistic), and LTC Paul Ironhorse (an overly-eager and absurdly anal-retentive military officer).The series is steeped in political correctness, right down to the choice of charactors (a vegetarian, a "black," a "native-American," and so on). Indeed, when it came to choosing the actors, it appears far more importance was placed on political correctness than acting ability. The same might be said for writers able to maintain a consistent premise and believable scripts.The first season ends with a silly, dancing, arm-waving, spaced-out sounding, female android, in black dance leotards (dance leotards must be sold all over the universe), from still another planet offering mankind help in the fight against the aliens, only to represent another threat to Earth - mankind as food for those on her planet (perhaps they have to eat well to maintain enough energy for all that absurd dancing and arm-waving).
summary: Good Premise Spoiled by Inconsistencies & Absurd Content.

reviewText: I purchased WAR OF THE WORLDS--Season One NEW/Factory Sealed in 2005. If any other owners of this DVD set read this review, please have a look at your copy.  Hopefully your copy WON'T have DVD ROT like mine does!!!

reviewText: The plea to give a show a chance has never been more appropriate than with "War of the Worlds."  If you don't give it a chance, you won't even make it halfway through the pilot episode.  That's what almost happened to me.  This was another show I bought sight-unseen, based solely on the Amazon reviews.  Every other show I've bought that way turned out to be great ("Firefly," "Earth2," "Odyssey 5," "Red Dwarf"); but after watching a good bit of the pilot, I was beginning to think I'd finally gotten a dud.  For starters, I disliked all the main characters - and still do to a certain extent.  Harrison Blackwood (Jared Martin) is an arrogant SOB; Suzanne McCullough (Lynda Mason Greene) is an airhead; Norton (Philip Akin) is just plain weird, but in saccharine sort of way; only Colonel Ironhorse (Richard Chaves), wooden and predictable as he is, comes off as having the least bit of sense or the least commitment to the project of saving the world from the aliens.  Even worse than the characters is the unbelievably slow start - not just with the pilot but with all the episodes.Once the story gets going, however, something magical begins to happen.  Each story is not only unique and original, it becomes totally engrossing.  This is a sci-fi show that "takes no prisoners."  The aliens take over the body of anyone they think might benefit them - even old folks and kids; they kill indiscriminately, often horrendously; and they even resort to vivisection to help their cause. They see humans as worthless fools and act accordingly.All of the episode titles have religious connotations, though sometimes the title bears little relationship to the actual plot.  And even though the aliens always get more or less foiled in whatever they're plotting, the resolution is never obvious and never certain - but it does always proceed logically from the plotline itself; the resolution isn't simply tacked on at the end like some Deus ex Machina the way a lot of sci-fi shows do.So if you stick with this show, and grit your teeth whenever the main characters come on, you'll be rewarded with one of the most truly original series ever created.

reviewText: Perhaps because I'm a fan of Canadian TV productions, I was especially disappointed in this TV series.The fx barely compete with the original '60s STAR TREK series of a generation before it (and are nowhere close to V, BABYLON FIVE, GALLACTICA, etc.), which is not a serious criterion or problem for me. (The clips from the old Gene Barry film are fun.)But the snail-paced pilot script is fraught with cliche situations.  Lotsa jolly drunks above the USA border apparently, as well as humorless aliens with a penchant for English (and Canadian French?) who are lightyears less dimensional than those on ALIEN NATION or even THE SIMPSONS.The stale dialogue also echoes from Saturday morning cartoon adventures of earlier decades--perhaps those space adventures with frozen faces and superimposed moving mouths, or the series that actually featured marionettes as "actors" except the marionettes were less wooden. Banter aspires to quips at the A-TEAM/ CHARLIE'S ANGELS riposte level, and never succeeds (especially when uttered by the self-delighted computer geek or the Professor from GILLIGAN'S ISLAND).Most grating, however, is the tedious gestalt cast of protagonists:* the usual Black computer geek (Majel's version was far more engaging when aliens again invaded Earth several years later) this time in a gimmicky wheel chair, no less, to parallel NEXT GENERATION's blind Black counterpart;* an annoyingly faux nag of a girlfriend (perhaps a clone of the equally shrill ex-wife on HILL STREET BLUES--was the actress here also a series producer's talentless wife?);* a heroine with no dimension for the actress to plumb (rather than a scientist's brainy daughter, this one's a military bigwig's brainy niece);* a brooding Indian (this is Canadian, afer all; what, no Pierre?) who's not too awful and could probably share a pleasant campfire on VOYAGER's holodeck;* and worst of all the smug swaggering "macho professor" hero, complete with Indiana Jones's fedora and Ford's actual first name!  It's this pompous, bland lead that does in the series.Watching the pilot episode seemed like a wormhole eternity.
summary: Less Tom Baker WHO than '50s SPACE CADETS

reviewText: I read the other reviews and wondered if we were talking about the same TV series.  I bought this set as I remembered the series and had some fond memories of it but people should not be fooled into thinking this is good television.What do you want from your television series?Good Acting?  Forget it.  The acting is terrible and it's surprising to see that some of the main actors did get other work.  Chaves and Martin are especially bad.  Akin had a fluctuating Jamaican accent in the first few episodes before getting rid of it completely.  (Odd since Akin is originally from Jamaica.)Interesting Premise?  On paper it must have looked good but you can't have a follow-up 30 years after a major world-wide invasion - one in which atomic weapons were used - and then throw out a plot gimmick that people have some type of human or alien amnesia.  They have to do this to create the tension about if they'll be closed down or having to use false identification.  It would have been much better if they just acknowledged that people remembered and they worked outwardly.Original Plots?  Some were interesting but nothing we had not seen on eariler series and certainly on later series.Character Conflict?  Well there is some of that but as contrived as it can be.  Take wing-nut, new age like scientist and throw him into a team with a straight laced military guy.  Unfortunately the moralizing and arguing between the main characters slows down many plotlines.Good effects?  I'll give them this to a degree since there really aren't too many effects.  Certainly as good as any other 1960 television show (ignoring that WofW was in the 1980's).Good editing?  The terrible editing is almost worth the cost alone.  For people who like to find continuity errors -  you'll be in heaven.  One moment some actor is running down stairs with a machine gun in his hands; he rounds the landing and continues downward sans machine gun.  Someone says the doors to the landing above them is locked but then the villian goes up to the next landing and enters.  The camera pans upward on a large city office building to a corporate meeting being held inside but the view out the window of the meeting room is at ground level with trees and lawn in the background.Finally, and this is a pet peeve of mine for many TV shows.  Although I'm a Canadian, I hate it when TV series are filmed in Canada and when we go into the field, the images always look like Canada regardless if the caption reads some other country or American state.  Scully and Mulder had the worst luck for no matter where they went, it was always raining.  On Stargate every planet they visit looks like typical British Columbia forest.  Smallville, supposedly in Kansas, has more snow on tv than the state likely gets in a year.  But to the credit of recent television shows - they try to disguise the location.  In War of the Worlds, filmed in Ontario, they didn't.  The caption may read some southeastern state and as the principals drive along  - outside the car you see snow on the ground.  In another the actors are leaving a restaurant, I think in Washington DC, but in huge letters outside the building are the initials for the Ontario Liquor Control Board.So in the end if you know the series and want to re-live it then buy these DVD's.  But it was quickly thrown together television with mediocre actors and poor production values.  It had potential but was not reached.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It is rather amazing that the syndicated television series version of "War of the Worlds" that debuted in 1988 works as well as it does.  That is because it paradoxically presents itself as a sequel to the classic 1953 science fiction film based on the novel by H.G. Wells and then proceeds to throw away all of the good stuff to make the scenario work as a weekly television series.  The narration that begins the title sequences explains each week:  "In 1953 Earth experienced a war of the worlds.  Common bacteria stopped the aliens but it didn't kill them.  Instead the aliens lapsed into a state of deep hibernation.  Now the aliens have been resurrected, more terrifying than before.  In 1953 aliens started taking over the world.  Today, they are taking over our bodies."Now, the iconic image of the Byron Haskin's film are the green Martian flying saucers moving slowly through the air destroying everything in sight when the death ray that comes out of the eye at the end of the serpentine neck.  But special effects cost a lot of money so forget that.  As for seeing the Martians, well, first of all the only thing you really get to see of them is their three finger hands, and secondly, the idea now is that the Martians awake from hibernation and start taking over human bodies.  That way you can hire actors to play them instead of having to pay for CGI or giant Martian suits, both of which are expensive.  The problem then is that you have turned "War of the Worlds" from what it is supposed to be, namely an all out war into more of an enemy infiltration effort.  This makes this version of "War of the Worlds" quite compatible with all of the alien invasion shows that debuted on television this year (e.g., "Invasion," "Threshold"), not to mention "The X-Files, " but it is no longer war between Earth and Mars (which Steven Spielberg's recent movie version reminds us is what Wells' story is really all about).The premise here is that the Martians invaded in 1953 and afterwards they were all sealed into barrels and put in a nuclear waste dump (conveniently most people have forgotten the war took place and even though who fought it do not remember the details, another example of how the series wants to have its cake but not eat it).  The Martians are accidentally released and start taking over human bodies so that they can survive in the bacterial cesspool that is Earth, so at least they have a decent justification for taking over people even if exactly how this is accomplished is one of those things you have to accept rather than actually understand.Fighting the fight are the quartet of Dr. Harrison Blackwood (Jared Martin), Dr. Suzanne McCullough (Lynda Mason Green), computer geek Norton Drake (Philip Akin), and military tough guy Lt. Col. Paul Ironhorse (Richard Chaves).  Sometimes McCullough brings her daughter, Debi (Rachel Blanchard) along for fun.  Harrison is the team leader and he is presented as the adopted son of Dr. Clayton Forrester, the Gene Barry character in the 1953 film.  For the most part these four fight the aliens on their own, with limited help from the government, mainly because more likely that not anybody the government sends is actually an alien.  So while the number of aliens who have taken over humans grows each week and there are apparently 10,000 out there, it is still just these four trying to do something about it.Despite these severe restraints this is not a bad television series.  I liked the way they tried to work Orson Welles' celebrated 1938 radio broadcast into the show's mythology in "Eye for an Eye," even if it is not a smooth fit.  There is a nice nod to the original "Battlestar Galactica" when John Colicos shows up as a Martian who has been trapped in a human body since 1953 ("The Prodigal Son"), but the idea that if a Martian jumps into the body of a pregnant human that would create a half-breed is a bit much ("Unto Us a Child is Born").  Keeping everything cover week after week strains credulity as well, culminating when McCullough's ex-husband (Michael Parks), an investigative reporter, shows up to check out the story that Blackwood's team is killing "illegal" aliens.  But then we have episodes like "The Raising of Lazarus" where Nicolas Coster plays one of those scientists who think we should reason with the alien invaders and make it easier for them to kill us all and take over the world.Mostly each week another Martian plot to do just that has to be thwarted (remember, it only take one successful plot and it is game over, man, game over).  Early on the goal is simply to possess more human (e.g., "A Multitude of Idols"), but then the Martians want to release a deadly virus that melts human brains ("Goliath is My Name"), poison grain ("The Good Samaritan"), start a nuclear war ("Epiphany"), attack through subliminals in music ("Choirs of Angels"), and, worst of all, destroy global phone links ("The Meek Shall Inherit").  A lot of the problems with this series are minimalized because of Jared Martin's Blackwood, who has this neat bit involving a tuning fork when he is trying to remember something.  He is the character who not only gives the orders but connects the dots so you can understand what we are supposed to think is going on.  Unfortunately, by the end of this first season having established a routine the season finale, "The Angel of Death," shakes up things big time, setting up a second season that is almost as different from the first season as it is different from the movie that inspired it, which does not sound like a good thing to me.
summary: An okay sci-fi series, but why does it have to be a "War of the Worlds" sequel?

reviewText: This series was always hard on to get into . Even back in 88 when you had the premise of the world destroyed in 52 basically and now noone remembers it. It was just an abomination in that regard, however in spite of that it did have engaging episodes which is overcame this bad plotline.  And it turned out to be a decent show if  you never thought about the world forgetting the destruction bit. It has effects from the late 80's which looked great then and just like all flicks and tv I can't stand the wankers who say it hasn't aged well. They didn't make this to todays cgi effects standards because they didn't exist then and this goes for much older movies of course too. You watch older sci fi for the fun of it not to analyze effects really. Anyways this show remains decent but not great , a bad idea that actually is engaging often which is a good achievement.
summary: this one was always hard to swallow

reviewText: and we thought we had won it.  Well, not lost it.  The alien invaders died off, killed by Earth's germs.  Let's face it, mankind is germy.  Anyway, decades later the aliens are revived when terrorists attack a nuclear waste site.  It seems when you spill waste on them the radiation kills the germs and this allows them to awaken.  Now they plan to finish off what they started and that means finishing off mankind.  Six discs from 1988-1989 of one of the greatest TV series.  They used scenes from the movie and even had Ann Robinson as Sylvia Van Buren in three of the episodes which helps to link them to the 50's movie.Nothing in the way of extras, but the series does bring back memories and has such stars as John Vernon as General Wilson and John Colicos from Battlestar Galactica as the alien Quinn.  Also has Philip Akin, who was later in Highlander: The Series, as Norton Drake and Richard Chaves, who was in the first Predator movie, as Lt. Col. Paul Ironhorse.Great ideas, great lines, great characters.Only one mistake - when they aired the episode Among The Philistines this episode SHOULD have come AFTER The Prodigal Son and BEFORE The Last Supper.If you are a fan of War of the Worlds YOU must buy this box set.

reviewText: As a cost-cutting measure, the TV series dumped everything except the name and a few props from the 1953 George Pal movie.  The aliens could "jump into" humans and take over their bodies.  This saved on rubber suits and puppets, I guess.  It became more of a pale imitation of "The Invasion of the Body Snatchers".  They made a big deal that the host-bodies were indistinguishable from normal bodies.  Did no one think of WEIGHING them?  A 150# alien jumps into a 120# woman's body, it's kind of odd she'd tip the scales at 270#, isn't it?That being said the series had its moments.  The dialogue was at times witty and intelligent, the actors did their best with the material, and there were some genuinely suspenseful moments.  The aliens were played intelligently and in some cases with humor.I'm talking about the 1st season.  Season 2 was a confused mess.  Suddenly the 1st set of aliens vanished and a whole new alien menace appeared.  I wouldn't give that 1 star.  If you liked John Carpenter's "The Thing" or either of the "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" movies, Season One is a worthy effort.  If you're looking for Tom Cruise in WoTW, this ain't it.
summary: Fairly typical TV conversion of a classic SF film.

reviewText: I find it strange that every good review on here, claims that the first season is better than the second. I would have to disagree. The first season is crammed with poor acting, terrible plotting and dialogue that would make you scream. In comparison, the second series killed off the worst offenders and shifted the action to an urban wasteland, bringing a completely different focus to the alien menace.I found it was a far better plot device to remove the military support from the main cast and cut them loose to fight the aliens alone in a nearly ruined urban nightmare.If this were the second series, I would buy it. The first season does nothing for me.

reviewText: I know the WOTW fanatics are going to go nuts over this review because I'm going against the grain but I always though the first season was too campy and silly and derived way too much from the 1953 movie.The second season with it's dark, paranoid, chaotic, Blade Runner-esque atmosphere fit the concept of an alien invasion much better.  The dim lighting(from filming at a more northernly latitude in Vancouver) was a precursor to the dim lighting in the early seasons of The X-Files and currently on FRINGE.  It gave it more of a "spooky" and serious tone.Hopefully Paramount will release the 2nd Season on DVD.
summary: I Actually Prefer The Second Season

reviewText: I had not even heard that such a TV series existed until around the time the 2005 remake came out. First things first: The only reason this first season even made it out onto DVD was to ride the coattails of the 2005 remake release on DVD. Indeed, this first season DVD set was released on the same day as the 2005 remake on DVD. The only reason I bought this first season set was because a retailer had the entire set on the release date for only $14.99. I'm not much for blind buys, but I bit. And I'd say it's worth the $15, and maybe a bit more. Maybe.Fans of the original film will find some interest in the TV series' attempts (sometimes successful) to link this TV series to the original film (and even the radio broadcast!). The best parts of the entire series are the relatively few sequences when we see the original spaceships from the '53 film. Unfortunately, the writers of the series didn't make much effort to explain the fact that in this 1988-89 world in which the events of the '53 film have taken place, nobody knows that it happened. This is never explained, and it is puzzling that not even a half-attempt was made to explain this. Mass amnesia apparently.The pacing and writing of the show is really odd. At certain points, the show drags and drags and doesn't seem to move forward at all, with way too much exposition or too much footage of things that could be edited down. The opening of many episodes are like this. On the other hand, there are other times when events or endings are confusing. Not confusing in a sense that the show is too complicated, but rather confusing in that it sometimes seems like entire sets of lines or scenes are missing that should explain what is going on and what the implications of a given event are. (A bit of a spoiler coming here:) One episode in particular, in which Blackwood begins to date a woman who is being abducted by aliens, ends totally abruptly. The format of the series up to this point led me to believe that this episode was the first of two parts. But no, this was the ending as it was meant. Completely unresolved, without any explanation. Strange.Now, I am by no means a snooty film fan, or even a snooty sci-fi fan. I can handle some pretty mediocre acting, writing, production, etc. When actors are bad enough that I can tell, then they're pretty bad. The set of actors on this season are shockingly and in fact hilariously poor actors. I think some of them might actually be decent actors, so I have to be fair and point out that the writing was probably the main culprit in the laughable nature of many scenes.This DVD set presents the show in so-so video quality. The bitrate seems to fine on the DVD's, so I think the iffy quality has to do with the source material, not the mastering of the DVD's themselves. The quality is more than watchable, it just isn't as good as most late 80's TV shows shot on film. This show, like other shows such as "Star Trek: The Next Generation", was shot on film but then edited in the videotape realm, where the special effects were also added. So the resulting masters used to make this DVD set are not film, but video masters. This results in quality that is lesser than one you would find from a direct film transfer from the late 80's, and also results in the rather wonky special effects that don't seem to match up with the film at all in terms of look or quality. I've heard some complaints stating that old off-air VHS copies look as good or better than this set. I have nothing to do compare it to.But for fans of WOTW and campy, quirky sci-fi, this set is not bad if you can find it for a decent price. Be prepared to occasionally be left hanging or disappointed with episode endings and plot development.
summary: Interesting for WOTW Fans and Unintentionally Funny for All
Title: N/A

reviewText: The first season of War of the Worlds was really very good for a low budget sci-fi TV show from the late 1980s. Good stories, likeable characters, and a quirky sense of humor make this a fondly remembered favorite. The second season, however, should be avoided at all costs.Sadly, the the picture quality of this DVD release is quite poor. There's considerable color bleeding and artifacting noticeable, especially in darker scenes. It's quite distracting. The image is often too soft and it's extremely difficult to make out detail. Audio sometimes appears very slightly out of sync. And why, oh, why did Paramount see fit to cut out the little sequence at the start of each episode where the alien hand encompasses the Earth? Clearly, very little care was given to this release by the studio.I highly recommend this show to any sci-fi fans, but the DVD release was a bit disappointing.

reviewText: This campy 80's sci-fi TV series made it onto the air for one reason and one reason only. There was a screen writer's strike and none of the major studios were able to get anything out of the studios and onto the little screen. This gave small, low budget, non-union independant producers the chance to get some of their stuff onto the little screen.Most of these shows went away as soon as the writer's strike was over, but this one weathered the storm, and even made it back for a second season. It was entertaining, with campy, inept aliens, radioactive after having been stored in nuclear waste for 50 years, taking possession of human bodies and bungling their way through failed attempts to conquer earth. The aliens even managed to get one of the original 1953 space ships running again, before crashing it again. I swear they used some of the original special effects footage from the 50's movie in the series. Their feeble efforts were what made the series so hilarious, it's a shame they f'ed the original theme up so badly in the second season. If they had just left it like it was, it might still be on the air. Probably not, but it would have at least made it through the second season before getting the ax.Maybe the second season will make it onto the DVD, but maybe not because it was SO bad. But the first season was great, it's good that it made it onto DVD.
summary: Loved it for what it was.......pure camp, worthy of Ed Wood
Title: N/A

reviewText: War Of The Worlds the series, came about in the syndicated 80's, where there was a great deal of syndicated shows that went around the networks and provided first run programming for independent stations (which have pretty much all became Fox,UPN or WB affilates now), the only problem with the shows was the lack of a network budget, Star Trek Next Gen aside.The premise of the show was that after the 1953 invasion the <martians> the show if I remember right put the aliens not from mars, but from a planet outside our solar system, mars was a staging ground for their invasion, our bacteria didn't kill the aliens but put them in suspended hibernation, after a terrorist attack on a military facility which the aliens were stored they awoke, and took over human bodies to try again to take over the world.The show also used the premise that a mass alien amensia weapon of some sort made humanity forget the invasion, which was kind of a stupid premise since there would be photo's,film and the fact that cities all around the world had to be rebuilt, the reason again was budget,if the writers went that humanity remembered the history of the world would be different, better the amnesia angle so that everything would be pretty much the same as in our world, and they never showed the aliens other than the hands,instead used the cheaper way of aliens can take over human bodies to keep the show in the low budget.But the series was good, well until the second season and worth a look if you didn't get to see it the first time around.
summary: Good show though with a better budget would have been great.

reviewText: I'm surprised to see some of the reviews here regarding video quality.  While there are problems, which I shall adumbrate upon later, it's not an unmitigated disaster of a release.  and HDTV's inherant quality will make any artifact show - and worsened by larger size monitors; and I've seen many LCD sets in stores display a uniform "block-like" pixelated look to DVDs they are playing; DVD titles I do own and can say are not caused by a poor DVD conversion... (even on a computer monitor, which is better than HDTV too.)But first things first, what makes this series special and which episodes should I recommend?I first have to say, this show is NOT for young children.  It can be violent and bloody at times.  The producers wisely chose to show that these aliens do not mean us well.  Violence is not something to be toyed with or used aimlessly like many American shows do.  But this one generally puts in the violence message very thoughtfully. But it is gruesome.  And I say "generally" because a couple of episodes do seem pointlessly gratuitous, however... but nobody's perfect.A continuation of "The War of the Worlds", it is 35 years later.  The entombed aliens are accidentally released and the war continues...  What makes this series cool is the gamut of characterizations.  Harrison Blackwood is a competent yet off-the-wall sort whose intuition serves him and the group well.  He's also a distant relative of Clayton Forrester (from the 1953 movie).  Suzanne McCulloch is a no-nonsense scientist.  Colonel Ironhorse is the military liason (and he does not want to  be around Harrison).  He's also a Republican in political ideology, which is quite an interesting take.  And then there's computer whiz Norton Drake who's a bit like all the others but has something else all his own in his persona.  It's a great mix of characters that works well as a group, even though you know the last thing they want is to have to work together!  Not since "Blake's 7" have I seen such a group of such disparate characters having to work together.Episodes to watch are:THE RESSURECTION.  The 90 minute pilot that sets up the whole kit'n'kaboodle.  It's nicely done all around and it's rare I can watch a pilot story and actually re-watch it later on without pulling my hair out from abject boredom.THE WALLS OF JERICHO.  Some time after "The Ressurection", it is revealed the aliens are alive and well.  Harrison has to convince Ironhorse of the threat.  There's not much of story depth in this episode (the aliens are alive, let's convince everyone to stop them), yet I find the interplay so entertaining that I had to include it in my "must see" list.  There are some nice set pieces as well.THY KINGDOM COME.  Sylvia Van Buren (Ann Robinson from the 1953 movie!) reprises her role.  Her experience with the aliens from that invasion gives her a unique insight, not to mention psychosis as she has been locked up in a mental asylum for some time.  This is a good episode as well for more character conflict, along with tying in the original movie with the 'new' series.  And there are some great set pieces too.EYE FOR AN EYE.  I never thought they'd get this right, but this one ties in the 1938 Orson Welles radio play as being "the first invasion".  The interplay between our group of heros and the local townspeople, not all of which believe there was an invasion, is fantastic.THE SECOND SEAL.  It barely makes it into this list and the plot simple:  The aliens have found a bunker containing more of their brethern, along with their technology and weaponary.  There are enough good moments for me to include this one.AMONG THE PHILISTINES.  Harrison and co. consult with a noted linguist to decipher alien communications.  Unfortunately, the linguist had already been taken over by the aliens...DUST TO DUST.  An alien War ship has been hidden in an Indian reservation for thousands of years.  and the aliens have come to collect it.THE PRODIGAL SON.  *** BEST EPISODE EVER ***  John Colicos plays a man who had been taken over by an alien.  But the man's body is immune to the processes that are slowly killing off all the other aliens.  He knows he hates humans with a passion, but he also knows that if his brethern find him that he will be dissected and analyzed.  He's not keen on that either.  But it doesn't stop him from trying his own plan to conquer thye world by attempting to blackmail the United Nations.  This episode is rich in detail, rich i nexecution... and then to sweeten the pot they got John Colicos who delivers one heck of a performance!  It's not to be missed!  Superlative, sublime, and any S-word you can apply to it except for the derogatory ones, this one can't be rated high enough!  This one is a classic OF classics, and there's been precious little in sci-fi that compares to this episode ever since.THE MEEK SHALL INHEIT.  The aliens attempt to disrupt all Earth communications systems to render human society helpless in the event of an attack.UNTO US A CHILD IS BORN.  A gruesome yet interesting entry; an alien takes over a pregnant girl.  The baby born features strengths that would be of great help to the aliens.  This one is disturbing at times, but has enough originality in it.VENGEANCE IS MINE.  Ironhorse accidentally kills a human instead of an alien.  The woman's husband wants revenge...  I've always loved revenge-themed stories, but this one adds in the alien aspect and it is very well done.  A great Ironhorse-themed story.THE ANGEL OF DEATH.  It seems the galaxy isn't so small a place as a new alien species enters the party and starts killing off aliens.  But is the old adage "The enemy of an enemy is our friend" even remotely true?  Almost corny in some scenes, this one still has plenty going for it to make it a worthy contender in the list.It's a highly underrated series, even if it's a tad gruesome in spots (and pointlessly gratuitous in some episodes, making me wonder about the authors' understanding of the series - or lack OF understanding?  But those eps are few and far between).And now onto rating the DVD set itself:First off, the audio quality is lovely.  beautifully cleaned, it is crisp and rich in bass.  Nothing to complain about here, only praise.  Audio Quality = A.Case design and covers.  No frills stuff but it's passable.  The layout is easy to read, nice use of graphics in the background.  And each disc has the story title and a brief synopsis of the episode.  If anything, they could have done a bit better at aligning the paper insert in the back of the plastic case.  But they are good cases too, not flimsy.  Packaging quality = A-The menu system is very nice.  Simple and effective, no animations to waste our time and disc space with, yet has some thought put into it.  What gives it an up mark is that it gives you an option to go to the menu or watch previews for unrelated shows I won't ever give a lab rat's about when you put in the disc.  This is very thoughtful on Paramount's part.  quality = AVideo quality:  Most of the problems are because of the source material aging for 17 years.  The saturation level is perfect.  Hardly drab or lifeless at all.  The image IS a bit on the soft side, however - they forgot to use a sharpening filter and probably didn't bother with a noise removal filter either.  The WOTW episodes, as with Trek TNG, were all shot on video then telecined to 35mm film to give it a uniform feel.  The video quality could be better, but I've seen far worse that gets passed as "stellar quality" by others.  Video quality = B, maybe B-.  Naah, B.  The price for the set is right enough and worse quality in other costly shows affects my judgment here.  Definitely a B.DVD compression quality:  Some scenes do show mpeg artifacting; which is a 'randomized' blocky effect.  But you really have to look to find it and, quite frankly, I've seen (and commented on!) far worse quality in other DVD releases.  Even releases I've praised in the past, when looking back, have more artifacting issues than this set does - and I still rate them highly enough.  Xfer quality:  B.It looks like they chopped out the opening alien hand animation at the start of the episode (it's a 'trademark' thing some fans will understandable hate) plus they took out the audio voiceover that accompanies the episode title.  (for some, or so I've read.  I've seen only disc 1 so far, but not the others - which I'm assuming are the same.)Overall quality = B-.  But I'd say "B" because the cost is realistic, unlike that of Paramount's most famous cash cow.  The only real problem here is the lack of sharpness from the source analogue material (film), but these did come from the master reels and not a 2nd gen VHS copy.  (I happen to have 2nd gen copies of the original broadcasts and they are infinitely worse in video quality!)  So they did do some restoration, just not enough to give this the "A" it ought to have.
summary: GREAT series, good but not great transfer quality, highly recommended.

reviewerName: Wayne Klein "If at first the idea is not absu...
reviewText: "War of the Worlds" acts as a sequel to the 1953 film classic. The idea behind this sequel is that the bacteria that appeared to kill the Martians didn't kill them at all--they went into hibernation. The bodies were stored near a nuclear waste dump where the radiation revived the aliens by killing the bacteria. Now, though, they've figured out a way to take over human bodies and resume their invasion.Dr. Harrison Blackwood (Jared Martin)and his team intercept radio broadcasts coming from space. Blackwood discovers though that there's a response back in an alien tongue and it's local.  Blackwood (the adopted son of Dr. Clayton Forrester hero of the first film) puts two and two together realizing that the aliens have returned to finish what they started. Ultimately Blackwood and his small team wage the battle on their own.While it had a fascinating premise and many strong episodes, "War of the Worlds" suffered from some of the problems of 80's syndicated TV--namely a low budget. The budget didn't allow the show to explore the concept as well as it could have. The actors gave solid performances and the writing could be quite good. Jared Martin and the other actors in the show do a good job with the material they're given. Also look for Ann Robinson from the original movie who shows up during a couple of episodes.Paramount's DVD release doesn't even look like they went back to the master film to remaster this. It looks as if it was taken from the original videotapes prepared for broadcast. As such, the image quality is OK as is the stereo soundtrack. It's a pity because it appears that this was put together very quickly for release without much thought of remastering the show. There aren't any extras other than previews for other Paramount TV shows on DVD.

reviewText: This show was presented as a continuation of the original Martian invasion, which occurred decades earlier.When watching this show, you must definitely keep in mind the time period in which it was created.
